> @qiluo-msft @ganglyu I addressed one issue with the test due to authentication changes coming from newly added test cases. However, the test still fails. I can see from the logs that the gnmi server on the device receives an Update list instead of a Replace list:
> 
> ```
> I0501 18:52:44.385066 777 server.go:608] Update path: path:{elem:{name:"CONFIG_DB"} elem:{name:"localhost"}}
> ```
> 
> This is the error I would expect if the fix added in [sonic-net/sonic-buildimage#22355](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22355) is not being pulled in. Is there a way to verify whether those changes are being used for these test runs? If so, then there is presumably some issue with the tool fix and I'll need to investigate further. If not, how can we ensure these test runs are using the most up-to-date version of the toolchain?

I pulled the latest PTF docker container (`docker pull sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf:latest`) and verified that the changes from https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22355 are there. I also verified that when the test runs using the modified gnxi script it passes successfully. So the test is valid, and the change to the gnxi tool is valid, and the modified gnxi tool is available in the latest `docker-ptf` container, but somehow the ElasticTest system is not using the correct PTF container. I think that container is getting set here https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/tests/pipelines/cont-warmboot.yml#L122 but I can't quite tell how that's working as I'm not familiar with the ElasticTest platform. It seems like it creates a unique PTF container for each test run, based off of a build number. @qiluo-msft @ganglyu @dt-nexthop @bhouse-nexthop any thoughts on this?

@anders-nexthop can you verify https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/azure-pipelines.yml#L86-L104 which is choosing between tag `py3only` and `latest`, that the `py3only` container actually has your changes too? I wonder if `py3only` isn't being updated any more since sonic-buildimage switched to *always* being `SONIC_PTF_ENV_PY_VER=py3` as per https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22409. As if now days only the `latest` ptf is being built that would explain the error.

You can see from the test case failure link that it chose the `py3only` image and not `latest`: https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=840347&view=logs&j=8b5da791-4df5-594e-e5e0-050f075410e7&t=0f13ada6-c985-5b90-1caa-4ec6d72aa24a&l=11

> @anders-nexthop can you verify
> 
> https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/azure-pipelines.yml#L86-L104
> 
> which is choosing between tag `py3only` and `latest`, that the `py3only` container actually has your changes too? I wonder if `py3only` isn't being updated any more since sonic-buildimage switched to _always_ being `SONIC_PTF_ENV_PY_VER=py3` as per [sonic-net/sonic-buildimage#22409](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22409). As if now days only the `latest` ptf is being built that would explain the error.
> You can see from the test case failure link that it chose the `py3only` image and not `latest`: https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=840347&view=logs&j=8b5da791-4df5-594e-e5e0-050f075410e7&t=0f13ada6-c985-5b90-1caa-4ec6d72aa24a&l=11

I have verified that `py3only` container does not have my changes. The container image seems pretty outdated:

```
(venv) [anders@ds103 sonic-mgmt]$ docker image ls | grep docker-ptf
sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf latest a2c7195a00b2 27 hours ago 1.52GB
sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf py3only c13e69685c39 2 months ago 1.51GB
```

It seems like it would be enough to rebuild `py3only` and push an updated container image. @qiluo-msft do you know how we would go about updating `py3only` container in the registry?
pretty sure `latest` is really only py3 now days, right? So maybe the better approach is to modify the azure pipeline to never use the `:py3only` image anymore.

> pretty sure `latest` is really only py3 now days, right? So maybe the better approach is to modify the azure pipeline to never use the `:py3only` image anymore.

actually wait, in progress #18209 :)
